children.name: able to make decisions or do things by yourself
independent b1
children.definition: independent able to make your own decisions, organize your own life, and do things in your own way, without wanting help or advice from other people: tự lập
examples: ▪ i quite like living alone. it’s made me more independent
▪ i’ve always been attracted to strong, independent women.
▪ joe’s still not very independent, and he tends to follow me around.
now that my sons are more independent, i have more time for myself.
an independent young woman
he’s helping other people with spinal injuries to lead an independent life.
independent of sbnot dependent on them
by this age, the child becomes relatively independent of his mother.
▪ i suddenly realised that my precious son was a full-grown man, quite independent of his father and me.

children.name: self-reliant c2
children.definition: self-reliant/ˌself rɪˈlaɪənt◂/  able to do things for yourself and solve problems by yourself, and able to live without depending on anyone else: tự lực
examples: my parents raised me to be self-reliant, and not to depend on anyone.
our aim is to teach our son to become an independent self-reliant adult.

children.name: self-sufficient c2
children.definition: self-sufficient able to live happily on your own, without needing a lot of friends or spending a lot of time with other people: tự lập
examples: ▪ we grew up in a close-knit, self-sufficient family with few outside friends.
▪ his father died when he was seven, and consequently joe learned to be self-sufficient from an early age.

children.name: not needing supplies from other people
independent b1
children.definition: independent having your own money and not needing financial help from other people: tự lập
examples: ▪ my mom was in fact quite independent. she had always had a job and her own bank account.
▪ changes in the rural economy turned many independent farmers to hired labourers.
financially independent
dad left me all his money when he died, which made me financially independent.
it was always very important to me to befinancially independent.
independent of
robert aimed to be independent of his parents by the time he was twenty.

children.name: self-sufficient c2
children.definition: self-sufficient able to provide all the things you need without help from other people : tự cung, tự cấp
examples: a self-sufficient farm
the amish belong to a self-sufficient community that has existed for over 200 years
self-sufficient in
australia is 65% self-sufficient in oil.
britain used to be fully self-sufficient in coal

children.name: to live in an independent way
be independent b1
children.definition: be independent/lead an independent life/biː ˌɪndˈpendənt, liːd ən ˌɪndpendənt ˈlaɪf/  to live in an independent way, without other people helping you or telling you what to do:
examples: độc lập ,tự lập
▪ alice was glad to be independent and making a life of her own at last.
▪ what strategies does a growing child use to become independent?
▪ our main objective is to help disabled people lead independent lives within the community.

children.name: stand on your own feet x
children.definition: stand on your own (two) feet/ˌstænd ɒn jɔːr ˌəʊn tuː ˈfiːt/  informal to live your life independently without any help from your family or the government: đứng trên đôi chân của mình
examples: ▪ she’ll never learn to stand on her own feet if you keep giving her whatever she wants.
▪ a year abroad gives students the chance to stand on their own two feet.

children.name: take care of yourself a2
children.definition: take care of yourselfalsolook after yourself /teɪk ˌkeər əv jɔːʳˈself, lʊk ˌɑːftəʳ jɔːʳˈselfǁ-ˌæf-/  especially british to cook your own food, wash your own clothes, and do other basic things that are necessary to live:
examples: ▪ grandpa can’t take care of himself any more so he’s coming to live with us.
▪ many youngsters who’ve been brought up in care are often incapable of looking after themselves when they leave.

children.name: go it alone x
children.definition: go it alone informal to start working or living on your own, especially after working or living with other people in a family, organization etc: tự làm một mình
examples: ▪ the response to our proposal was lukewarm, so we felt we had to go it alone.
▪ after years of working for a big company, she decided to go it alone and set up her own business.
▪ when it comes to parenthood, more and more women are deciding to go it alone.

children.name: do your own thing c1
children.definition: do your own thing/ˌduː jɔːr əʊn ˈθɪŋ/  spoken to live in an independent way and do what you want to do, without being influenced by what other people think:
examples: ▪ he has a couple of roommates but they kind of all do their own thing.
▪ he’s given up his job and is living in northern california, just doing his own thing.

children.name: fend for yourself c2
children.definition: fend for yourself written to look after yourself, when you are used to being taken care of by someone else, or when being independent is very difficult: tự lo cho bản thân
examples: ▪ the mother died before the cubs were old enough to fend for themselves.
▪ dad always wanted me to be able to fend for myself from a very early age.
▪ the children were left to fend for themselves on the streets.

children.name: by yourself without help or advice
helpless c1
children.definition: helpless needing help because you cannot do anything for yourself or you need protection:
examples: ▪ why are you so afraid of a helpless old woman?
▪ frightened and helpless, alvin wondered if they might kill him.
utterly helpless
▪ his mother’s death left the boy feeling utterly helpless and alone.
helplessly[adverb]
▪ i started to cry as helplessly as a baby.

children.name: on your own b1
children.definition: on your own if you do something on your own you do it without help from anyone else:tự mình
examples: ▪ i doubt i would have been able to find this job on my own.
all on your ownuse this to emphasize that sb does sth on their own
he went to china all on his own.
did you do that all by yourself then?
▪ you mean to tell me he painted the whole house all on his own?

children.name: by yourself a2
children.definition: by yourself if you do by yourself you do it without help from anyone else:tự mình
examples: ▪ peter cooked everything by himself - he wouldn’t even let me in the kitchen.
all by yourselfuse this to emphasize that sb does sth on their own
he went to china all on his own.
did you do that all by yourself then?
▪ you mean to tell me he painted the whole house all by himself?

children.name: independently b2
children.definition: independently/ˌɪndɪˈpendəntli, ˌɪndəˈpendəntli/  if you work or make decisions independently, you do not need help and advice from other people:
examples: tự lập, không phụ thuộc [trạng từ ] nếu bạn làm hoặc đưa ra quyết định 1 cách tự lập , bjan không cần sự giúc đỡ hay lời khuyên từ những người kahsc
▪ with a few exceptions, the students work well independently.
với 1 vài trường hợp ngoại lệ , những học sinh có thể thự mình làm tốt
▪ margaret wanted to live independently, but would she ever manage it?
margaret muốn sống tự lập nhưng cô ấy có thể quản lí được nó?
▪ once my child is writing independently, how can i help her become a more skillful speller?
1 khi con tôi tự mình viết , làm thế nào để tôi giúp nó trở thành 1 người viết thành thạo hơn ?

children.name: on your own initiative x
children.definition: on your own initiative using your own ideas about what needs to be done, instead of waiting for someone in authority to tell you what to do : tự mình, chủ động (không cần nhắc)
examples: she was always happy to work on her own initiative, and set her own goals and deadlines.
when he was only fourteen, he wrote, on his own initiative, to every airline, asking to join the company.
we think the bomb was placed by an extremist, acting on his own initiative.

children.name: under your own steam x
children.definition: under your own steam if you go somewhere under your own steam, you go there without help from anyone else: tự đi
examples: can you manage to get up to the house under your own steam while i bring up the food?
i never thought sal and thomas would make it here under their own steam!

children.name: independent in the way you think
think for yourself x
children.partOfSpeech: [verb phrase usually in infinitive or progressive]
children.definition: think for yourself/ˌθɪŋk fəʳ jɔːʳˈself/  to make decisions or form opinions without expecting other people to help or approve of you: tự nghĩ cho bản thân
examples: ▪ parents should encourage their children to think for themselves.
▪ the purpose of this question is to force students to think for themselves.
▪ ‘you’re going to have to start thinking for yourself,’ said david sternly.

children.name: have a mind of your own u
children.definition: have a mind of your own/hæv ə ˌmaɪnd əv jɔːr ˈəʊn/  to have a strong character and strong opinions that are not influenced by other people’s:
examples: nghĩ / hành động độc lập, có ý nghĩ riêng có tính cách mạnh mẽ hay những ý kiến mạnh mẽ mà không bị ảnh hưởng bởi người khác
▪ she’s a woman with a mind of her own, who says what she thinks.
cô ấy là người phụ nữ hành động độc lập , người nói những gì mà cô ấy nghĩ
▪ but mansell has a mind of his own, and he was adamant he would make racing his career.
nhưng masell có ý nghĩ riêng của mình , và ông ấy đã kiên quyết sẽ làm cho sự nghiệp đua xe của mình

children.name: know your own mind x
children.definition: know your own mind to have a strong character and be confident about what you want to do: biết mình muốn gì
examples: ▪ though not yet 15, sara knows her own mind, and has already decided on a career.
▪ i’m in my mid-thirties and ought to know my own mind by now, but i’m scared of getting married.

children.name: be your own man x
children.definition: be your own man/woman/biː jɔːr ˌəʊn ˈmæn, ˈwʊmən/  to be confident of your opinions, without letting other people influence you - use this when you approve of someone like this:
examples: hãy là chính bạn
▪ stan was intellectual, confident and above all, his own man.
▪ she didn’t want to quarrel with him, but made it plain that she was her own woman now, with her own life to lead.
▪ sheila is very much her own woman. she’ll listen to everyone and then make up her mind for herself.

children.name: independence b1
children.definition: independence
examples: he was desperate to get a job and regain his independence.
▪ roz said she’d never marry because she valued her independence too much.
▪ though they want to exert their independence, these kids are not quite ready for it.
▪ your first pay cheque gives you a terrific sense of independence
gain/win/achieve etc independence
▪ she no longer had that feeling of independence she had fought so hard to win.
financial/economic independence
▪ she worked hard to gain financial independence.

children.name: self-sufficiency x
children.definition: self-sufficiency when you are independent, either because you can live happily without needing a lot of friends, or because you do not need to buy food or other products from other places: tự lập, tự túc
examples: ▪ i admired his air of self-sufficiency.
▪ he promised to do more to help welfare recipients achieve self-sufficiency.
▪ the administration of native americans (ana) promotes the goal of social and economic self-sufficiency for indian tribes.

children.name: self-reliance x
children.definition: self-reliance when you are independent, because you can solve your own problems and are able to do things by yourself, and do not need the help or support of anyone else:
examples: ▪ the older children are beginning to develop self-reliance.
▪ both men display the fiery self-reliance that natives of oregon tend to possess.

children.name: dependence c2
children.definition: dependence when you depend on the help and support of someone or something else in order to exist or be successfulopp independence
examples: dependence on/upon
our dependence on oil as a source of energy
the financial dependency of some women on men

children.name: dependent b2
children.definition: dependent needing sb/sth in order to exist, be successful, be healthy etcopp independent
examples: dependent on/upon
norway’s economy isheavily dependenton natural resources.
jan’s mother wasdependent onherforphysical care.
do you have anydependent children(= who you are still supporting financially )?
